results.headline: Romantic Dissatisfaction and Career Frustration

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Helena from the Wedding

results.summary_short: In “Helena From the Wedding” a cozy cabin is the setting for themes of romantic dissatisfaction and career frustration among yuppies staring down 40.

results.headline: J. R. Ewing Shot Down Communism in Estonia

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Disco & Atomic War

results.summary_short: “Disco and Atomic War,” Jaak Kilmi’s lighthearted documentary, describes the effect of American television shows from Finland on the Soviet state in Estonia in the 1980s.

results.headline: The (Un)Making of an Art World Satirist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Con Artist

results.summary_short: Michael Sladek’s documentary, “Con Artist,” examines the artist Mark Kostabi, who has relentlessly spoofed the relationship between art and commerce.

results.headline: Captivating the Eye, Challenging the Brain

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bruce Conner Films 1

results.summary_short: In two programs, Film Forum is revisiting the work of an experimentalist who appealed to the brain as well as to the eye.

results.headline: Plenty of Perky, Even This Early

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Morning Glory

results.summary_short: Rachel McAdams plays a television producer in the romantic comedy “Morning Glory.”

results.headline: Western Meets Horror

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Hill

results.summary_short: “Red Hill” is a galloping revenge tale that uses young blood to unearth old sins.

results.headline: The Tale of a Shocking Fall and a Gritty Resolve

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 127 Hours

results.summary_short: Danny Boyle’s “127 Hours” recreates the ordeal of Aron Ralston, the hiker who decided to extricate himself from a narrow slot of rock by severing an arm.

results.headline: Animated Ambiguity, Featuring a Big Head

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Megamind

results.summary_short: Evil becomes good and vice versa in “Megamind,” a new 3-D fantasy from DreamWorks Animation.

results.headline: The Blissed-Out Rhythms of the Young and in Love
results.display_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench

results.summary_short: A Boston-based musical commentary on love and art, “Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench” floats on a wave of spontaneity and charm.

results.headline: Harebrained Plans by Half-Wits

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Lions

results.summary_short: “Four Lions,” directed by Chris Morris, is a stiletto-sharp satire about a group of bumbling terrorists.

results.headline: A Powerful Chorus Harmonizing ‘Dark Phrases of Womanhood’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For Colored Girls

results.summary_short: With “For Colored Girls” Tyler Perry works very hard and gets it mostly right.

results.headline: Marital Strife and C.I.A. Obligations

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fair Game

results.summary_short: Sean Penn and Naomi Watts star as Joseph Wilson and Valerie Plame Wilson, the couple at the center of the controversy over whether Iraq had weapons of mass destruction.

results.headline: Gal Takes Straighter Path, Hoping to Have It All

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Violet Tendencies

results.summary_short: Casper Andreas’s “Violet Tendencies” is an ugly-duckling fairy tale about a woman with lots of gay friends who decides she needs her own relationship with a man.

results.headline: A Stoic Marine Undone by Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Marine Story

results.summary_short: Closeted, forced out of the service, and now facing identity issues at home.

results.headline: Amok on the Road to Daddydom

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Due Date

results.summary_short: An odd-couple, buddy road movie, “Due Date” stars Zach Galifianakis and Robert Downey Jr. as reluctant car companions.

results.headline: The Really Strange Bedfellows That New York Politics Made

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Client 9

results.summary_short: Alex Gibney’s new documentary, “Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer,” examines the hubris and politics that played a role in Mr. Spitzer’s undoing.

results.headline: A Freshman Year to Remember

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cherry

results.summary_short: In “Cherry” Kyle Gallner stars as a freshman who falls for a 31-year-old fellow student — and her daughter.

results.headline: A Motel Stay Leads to Creepy Happenings

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beneath the Dark

results.summary_short: Not even the Bates Motel itself could save the mess that is “Beneath the Dark.”

results.headline: Algerian Brothers Reunite in Paris, Outrage Still Burning

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Outside the Law

results.summary_short: “Outside the Law,” Rachid Bouchareb’s sweeping historical melodrama of the Algerian struggle for independence, proceeds from a still-burning sense of outrage.

results.headline: Light and Shadow, and Music on the Wondrous, Dreamy Side

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ne change rien

results.summary_short: Pedro Costa’s unusual documentary “Ne Change Rien,” about the French singer and actress Jeanne Balibar, focuses on work — the performer’s mix of inspiration and hard labor.
